text:
I'd also argue that a lot of industries just aren't into SEO yet -- imo that's more likely than that they've tried and failed. I'm biased though because in my specific niche, we're dominating against our closest competitors just because none of them are really doing it and it's A HUGE sale channel for us :smile:

+1 to the idea of looking into Google Ads. And honestly, if they're getting good traffic from social, I'd argue that it can be easier in some ways to get a more consistent flow of traffic via SEO... so seems like it's worth a try

text: <@U016AG4A2G2> good questions. Big things to keep in mind I’d say, know the product inside and out and know the customers/market inside and out. Data and reports can only tell you so much. You need to deeply understand the customer and their motivations, and I’ve yet to see someone do this with data alone. You can always ask. If you’re the person who’s always drawing insights based on recent conversations with real customers you’ll bring huge value to the team. And don’t forget the “market” part of “marketing.” Conversations with existing customers are great, but you’ll learn tons from people who are in the market but haven’t bought yet, or are considering buying. I love in-person events (RIP) and conference booths for this reason. You can do all the behind-your-computer wordsmithing you want, but nothing compares to standing on your feet and pitching the product, explaining the benefits, in 100 face-to-face conversations in a day. If you have a sales team, definitely sit in on as many sales calls as you can and have regular conversations with the sales team.

elements.text: good questions. Big things to keep in mind I’d say, know the product inside and out and know the customers/market inside and out. Data and reports can only tell you so much. If you’re the person who’s always drawing insights based on recent conversations with real customers you’ll bring huge value to the team. And don’t forget the “market” part of “marketing.” Conversations with existing customers are great, but you’ll learn tons from people who are in the market but haven’t bought yet, or are considering buying. I love in-person events (RIP) and conference booths for this reason. You can do all the behind-your-computer wordsmithing you want, but nothing compares to standing on your feet and pitching the product, explaining the benefits, in 100 face-to-face conversations in a day. If you have a sales team, definitely sit in on as many sales calls as you can and have regular conversations with the sales team.

text: sort of <@UMX8MPHA6>, we define themes that we want to cover. But again, those are subject to change as well. text: :thinking_face:

Is that a common implementation of "Scrum" in the space?  According to that article, it's different enough from what software teams do that I'd revise my opinion on whether it makes sense for other disciplines (and, tangentially, whether "Scrum" is a good name for it).  If the idea is just to provide a way to reconcile short term focus ("sprints") with long term goals, ("product backlog," I guess?), then that seems reasonable.

elements.text: Is that a common implementation of "Scrum" in the space? text: My agency is asking that I write our “employee guidebook” and was wondering if anyone else has had experience with this. I am getting pushback because I think we need to include a bunch of HR and legal sections since a handbook is designed to lay out our policies and protect us in event of legal action. Any ideas on how to navigate this!?

elements.text: My agency is asking that I write our “employee guidebook” and was wondering if anyone else has had experience with this. I am getting pushback because I think we need to include a bunch of HR and legal sections since a handbook is designed to lay out our policies and protect us in event of legal action. Any ideas on how to navigate this!?

text: I've written the guidebook for my old agency before. it did include HR policies like attendance, work hours, behavior, etc. but no legal policies. For the most part it was like a "tips and tricks" handbook on the best ways to do your job

elements.text: I've written the guidebook for my old agency before. it did include HR policies like attendance, work hours, behavior, etc. but no legal policies. For the most part it was like a "tips and tricks" handbook on the best ways to do your job

text: not saying my approach was the right one, just providing perspective

elements.text: not saying my approach was the right one, just providing perspective

text: Thanks! I guess my question is: Once you create a handbook, aren’t you suddenly legally required to include many more things beyond how to do your job?

elements.text: Thanks! I guess my question is: Once you create a handbook, aren’t you suddenly legally required to include many more things beyond how to do your job?

text:
We have a series of these as strategy templates. They've been a big SEO win for us —we have the strategy as text on the page and then the template behind a gated form, so we get rankings + leads. While I don't have stats on how many people are actually using the google doc templates, we recently ran an a/b test with text next to the form vs. a gif of the template and the gif significantly increased our conversion rate, so seeing the template they were getting on the other side helped drive form conversion. We've sourced a number of clients from this (with a product that starts at 10k ARR)

<https://www.quorum.us/templates/government-relations-strategic-plan-template/>

attachments.title: Government Relations Strategic Plan Template
attachments.text: Is your organization’s success impacted by government policy at the federal, state, or local level? Stay organized with this document and don't miss a step while building your strategy. 1. Define Your Issues 2. Identify Your Legislative Champions 3. Build Relationships with Legislative Champions 4. Track Legislation 5. Communicate Updates to Legislators and Coalition Members 6. Integrate Grassroots Advocacy
attachments.fallback: Quorum: Government Relations Strategic Plan Template

elements.text: We have a series of these as strategy templates. They've been a big SEO win for us —we have the strategy as text on the page and then the template behind a gated form, so we get rankings + leads. text: As the owner of a business with employees, my take is that this is way out of scope for someone whose general purview is content for the org.  Granted, you'll almost certainly work from a template tailored to your state of incorporation, or states where you do business.  But such a document should include things like absence policies, PIPs, dress codes, workplace conduct, etc.

elements.text: As the owner of a business with employees, my take is that this is way out of scope for someone whose general purview is content for the org.  Granted, you'll almost certainly work from a template tailored to your state of incorporation, or states where you do business.  But such a document should include things like absence policies, PIPs, dress codes, workplace conduct, etc.

text: And, it's not that the handbook is legally binding itself; you're not creating a legal document.  But you're creating a document intended to communicate official/legal policy, so you don't really want to wing that.  Not to sell your research skills short, but the handbook should answer questions like "does it violate company policy for me to freelance in my spare time for agency clients and what are the legal repercussions for violating that policy?"  And I'm guessing you're not tasked with making those calls unilaterally.

elements.text: And, it's not that the handbook is legally binding itself; you're not creating a legal document.  But you're creating a document intended to communicate official/legal policy, so you don't really want to wing that.  Not to sell your research skills short, but the handbook should answer questions like "does it violate company policy for me to freelance in my spare time for agency clients and what are the legal repercussions for violating that policy?"  And I'm guessing you're not tasked with making those calls unilaterally.

text:
<@U017XD7H4P7> - my sentiment exactly. They assume I write so this falls under my purview. I keep bringing up policies that may not explicitly be defacto legal, but the very creation of this book is setting the standard and opening us up to legal liability. The co-founder essentially said “we’re almost completely in a position where nobody can sue us”

Anyhow, they want most of this to be like our brand and culture and ethos and then Ive been tasked with checking what I assume is our HR partner (outsourced) to see about the rest of my legal policy questions. I am truly in a bind here as my specialty is not constructing these documents.
